Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Physical Shaping of Multicellular Mesenchymal Tissues
Award.AbstractNarration: During early development mesenchymal cells migrate, rearrange, and change shape to remodel the embryo. Coordinated movements of loosely-packed mesenchymal cells in the early embryo construct the vertebrate body plan and populate tissues in preparation for the construction of muscles, connective tissue and bone, as well as the lymphatic and circulatory systems. Many genes and many cells participate in these events, but there is little experimental evidence on how genes and cells generate physical forces and integrate biochemical pathways to drive mechanical movements within embryos. The goal of this research is to investigate how genes control the physical mechanics of multicellular mesenchymal tissues by: 1) analyzing the physics of re-aggregation and the cellular mechanics responsible for rapid phases of tissue sculpting, 2) challenging cells with varied micro-environments and assessing how their behavior changes, and 3)vary levels of cell adhesion molecules and surface contractility to reveal how mesenchymal tissue spreading and engulfment are mechanically coordinated. Understanding the molecular basis of rules governing the ordered assembly of mesenchymal tissue will explain how events at the subcellular scale coordinate cell behaviors during assembly of organs and functional tissues. These findings will complement and extend efforts to understand the molecular basis of mesenchymal morphogenesis and begin the process of integrating the molecular machinery into larger "morphogenetic" processes that are robust and may be adapted by tissue engineers. The cross- and interdisciplinary training resulting from this project will provide biologists and tissue engineers the ability to integrate learned concepts into a framework the will be important for both fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The complex and diverse animal forms that surround us are created by large scale movements of cells and tissues during embryonic development. Both adult and embryonic tissues are composed of mixtures of coherent groups of cells in sheets (epithelia) adjacent to multilayered masses of cells (mesenchyme). Cell sheets and masses coordinate their movements but little is known about the mechanical processes involved. This project has sought to identify the mechanical and cellular properties of mesenchymal and epithelial cells that make their coordinated movements possible.

Intellectual Merit:

To answer these questions we have chosen to carry out quantitative studies using embryonic tissues of the aquatic Africa claw-toed frog Xenopus laevis. Xenopus embryos have been used to explore the biochemical nature of cells and tissues for more than 100 years and offer exquisite opportunities to isolate cells and tissues and explore their behaviors when placed in unique controlled microenvironments. We have studied cell behaviors within composite tissues in a variety of mechanically complex environments, including 3D "forests" of micro-pillars, under complex conditions where their cohesion to each other and adhesion to their substrates have been altered, and where their size and shape have been explicitly controlled, e.g. as triangles or small circles. Together with scaffold-free culture approaches we have found mesenchymal cells removed from their epithelia exhibit novel cell behaviors and phenotypes.

Mesenchymal cells isolated from different parts of the embryo are remarkably different mechanically. For instance, early stage mesenchymal cells from the future skin round up quickly to form spheroids in a fluid-like manner whereas mesenchymal cells that will later form the back muscles maintain their shapes and behave as solids. As the embryo develops, some populations of mesenchymal cells give rise to organs such as the heart. These mesenchymal cells exhibit a range of complex behaviors as they exchange neighbors. As they move they can even transition to epithelial cells. The transition from mesenchyme to epithelial cell types is a key to the establishment of functional organs throughout the embryo. Such transitions can also occur in adults, for instance during cancer progression or in the formation of scars. Our discoveries of novel behaviors of mesenchymal cells during development in the frog embryo reveal novel biology and will shed light on human disease.

By placing mesenchymal and composite tissue into mechanically controlled environments we have discovered a range of novel phenomena which we are investigating at the molecular scale. For instance, when coupled in a composite, mesenchymal cell movements are guided by overlying epithelia and the topography of their substrates. Cells along sharp boundaries are less able to migrate than cells along a straight boundary. Mesenchymal cell movements within a tissue are also constrained by the size of the neighbors and the dimensions of obstacles in their microenvironment. Surprisingly, these constraints not only alter their speed but also how well cells can coordinate their movements with their neighbors.

We have tracked down the complex behaviors of mesenchymal cells to specific genetic pathways. For instance, the ability of cells to change from mesenchymal to epithelial involves their ability to sense changing levels of actomyosin contractility in themselves and their neighbors. Contractility regulates cohesion of mesenchymal cells and can mimic the effects of adhesion to a large extent. The ability of cells to adhere to one another also alters their ability to migrate as single cells; cadherin, a protein used for adhesion also controls Rac1 molecular switches that regulate single cell and collective migration.
